entry.title: Technical Notes
entry.content:
So I feel that I should add a few technical notes to this blog now that this is off the ground. As alluded to in my first post a few months ago, this site has gone through a few iterations. It began with a Wordpress.org account. However, that was quickly abandoned as I realized that for my purposes the features of a full blown WAMP/MAMP environment weren't necessary.

Instead, I needed something lighter, easier to maintain and, in my opinion, a lot more fun to customize. I had heard that Bootstrap provided many of those features. So while Boston slowly dug itself out earlier this year, I spent some time building out a single page site using the Bootstrap API. In fact, some of what you see on the "about" page comes from that exercise.

However, once I discovered Jekyll Bootstrap earlier this weekend, I knew I was sold on a framework. Jekyll Bootstrap allows an end user to quickly build out a blogging platform. It is lightweight, easy to deploy, fully customizable and, as an added bonus, hosts freely on Github. I've gotten a website off the ground within the past few days.

Now I can focus on blogging rather than maintaining a website.

stay tuned.

entry.title: A Year in Review
entry.content:
I moved to Somerville from the North Shore in September. While I’m still working on the North Shore, my commute has invariably risen from a seemingly quick 30 minute car ride to a 1.5 to 2 hour subway-to-commuter-rail marathon.

I’ve started reading. A lot.

Since January 2014, I’ve read:

# Author Work
1 Bukowski, Charles Hot Water Music
2 Carver, Raymond Cathedral
3 Carver, Raymond What We Talk About When We Talk About Love
4 Dumas, Alexandre The Count of Monte Cristo
5 Ellis, Bret Easton American Psycho
6 Fariña, Richard Been Down So Long it Looks Like Up to Me
7 Hajdu, David Positively 4th Street: The Lives and Times of Joan Baez, Bob Dylan, Mimi Baez Fariña, and Richard Fariña
8 Hemingway, Ernest The Old Man and the Sea
9 Hemingway, Ernest The Sun Also Rises
10 Ilgunas, Ken Walden on Wheels: On the Open Road from Debt to Freedom
11 Johnson, Denis Tree of Smoke
12 Kerouac, Jack Tristessa
13 Lahiri, Jhumpa The Namesake
14 Lampedusa, Giuseppe Tomasi di The Leopard
15 McCarthy, Cormac Blood Meridian, or the Evening Redness in the West
16 McMurtry, Larry Lonesome Dove
17 McCarthy, Cormac Blood Meridian, or the Evening Redness in the West
18 Millard, Candice The River of Doubt: Theodore Roosevelt’s Darkest Journey
19 Millard, Candice Destiny of the Republic: A Tale of Madness, Medicine and the Murder of a President
20 Mitchell, Joseph Up in the Old Hotel
21 Munro, Alice Dear Life: Stories
22 Munro, Alice Runaway
23 Piketty, Thomas Capital in the Twenty-First Century
24 Salter, James A Sport and a Pastime
25 Saunders, George Tenth of December
26 Saunders, George CivilWarLand in Bad Decline
27 Tower, Wells Everything Ravaged, Everything Burned
28 Wood, Pamela The Salt Book: Lobstering, Sea Moss Pudding, Stone Walls, Rum Running, Maple Syrup, Snowshoes, and Other Yankee Doings
29 Zweig, Stefan Beware of Pity

To be honest, I read most of these books this fall. I loved Candice Millard’s writing. Her ideas and sentences flowed seamlessly. I’ve recommended her to a few friends and even those who aren’t usually fans of popular history are really blown away by her captivating style. I was pleasantly surprised to see her interviewed on Ken Burns’ Roosevelts.

I feel that I should also note that I’ve gone on a bit of a short story kick. I struggled to put down the works of Carver, Munro, and Saunders.

Not recorded here are the countless times I spent picking up, and putting down, Infinite Jest. I just can’t seem to commit to that book. I feel like I’ll pick it up and get into it only to read a review or receive a recommendation and drop it for something more approachable. There’s so many other things I’m dying to read. Maybe I’ll go on a media blackout in 2015 and just force myself through it.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.content:
This site has been in the making for awhile now. Actually it lived and died in Wordpress for a brief period last fall and is finally live via Jekyll.

I’m using this blog to record my thoughts and projects specifically as they relate to my explorations in digital history. I think it’ll be useful to have a place to write down my blunders and (hopefully) get feedback from the larger DH community.

All the best –
